summary.seg: Corpus Christi College MS 403 transmits the so-called 'Byzantine triad' of three plays of Euripides (b. c. 480, d. 406 BC), selected for study in Byzantine schools: Hecuba, Orestes (wrongly entitled Electra) and Phoenician Women.
The texts follow the recension (i.e. redaction) of the Byzantine grammarian Manuel Moschopoulus Moschopoulos, Manuel, approximately 1265?- (13th-14th century; see Turyn 1957).

The first section (ff. 1r-41v) was copied by Hand A and comprises Hecuba and Orestes ll. 1-490; the scholia of this section are predominantly Moschopoulean. The second section (ff. 42r-118r) comprises Orestes ll. 491-end and Phoenician Women; this section was copied by Hand B, and, in addition to the Moschopoulean scholia, there are some ascribed to the Byzantine grammarian Thomas Magistros Thomas, Magistros, active 1310-1327 (13th-14th century).

Richard Porson Porson, Richard, 1759-1808 , Regius Professor of Greek at Cambridge (b. 1759, d. 1808), used this manuscript for his editions of Hecuba (1797, siglum C), Orestes (1798, siglum C.C.C. vel MS.C.C.C.), and Phoenissae (1799, siglum C); the manuscript had also been previously collated by Barnes, Joshua, 1654-1712 Joshua Barnes (b. 1654, d. 1712) for his edition of Euripides (Euripidis Quae Extant Omnia, 1694; only intermittent notes, e.g. on pp. 58, 65, 121, etc., on variants are from 'MS. Coll. Corpus Christi' or 'C.C.C.', i.e. CCCC MS 403, as explained by Porson in his edition of Euripides' tragedies: see the second edition, 1802, p. XVII). Before Barnes, King, John, 1696-1728 John King (b. 1696, d. 1728) collated the manuscript for his edition of the three plays ( Euripidis Hecuba, Orestes et Phoenissae, 1726).
J. Diggle designated the manuscript ('Cantabrigiensis 403') with siglum Xc in his Orestes edition (Oxford 1994).

msContents.textLang: Greek, with a few later annotations in Latin

msItem.author: Euripides
msItem.title: Hecabe
msItem.rubric: f. 1r Εὐριπίδου Ἑκάβη προλογίζει εἴδωλον πολυδώρου
msItem.incipit: f. 1r Ἥκω νεκρῶν κευθμῶνα καὶ σκότου πύλας λιπών ἵν’ ᾅδης χωρὶς ᾥκισται θεῶν
msItem.explicit: f. 30r τῶν δεσποσύνων πειρασόμεναι μόχθων· στερρὰ γὰρ ἀνάγκη
msItem.note: The text is accompanied by scholia and interlinear glosses in brown ink

msItem.title: Hypothesis on Orestes (Arg. 1 Dindorf, Scholia II 1863)
msItem.incipit: f. 30r Ὀρέστης τὸν φόνον τοῦ πατρὸς μεταπορευόμενος, ἀνεῖλεν αἴγισθον καὶ κλυταιμνήστραν
msItem.explicit: f. 30r ὀρέστην δὲ καὶ ἑρμιονην ἐπέταξε λαβεῖν· πυλάδῃ δὲ ἠλέκτρα συνοικῆσαι· καθαρθέντι δὲ τοῦ φόνου, ἄργους ἄρχειν

msItem.title: Hypothesis on Orestes (Arg. 2 Dindorf, Scholia II 1863)
Hypothesis of Aristophanes of Byzantium
msItem.incipit: f. 30v ἡ μὲν σκηνὴ τοῦ δράματος ὑπόκειται ἐν ἄργει. ὁ δὲ χορὸς συνέστηκεν ἐκ γυναικῶν ἀργείων, ἡλικιωτίδων ἠλέκτρας
msItem.explicit: f. 30v ὁ δρᾶμα τῶν ἐπὶ τοῖς σκηνῆς εὐδοκιμούντων· χείρισιν δὲ τοῖς ἤθεσι· πλὴν γὰρ πλ πυλάδου πάντες φαῦλοι ἦσαν
msItem.note: Followed by the list of characters of the play

msItem.author: Euripides
msItem.title: Orestes
msItem.incipit: f. 31r Οὐκ ἔστιν οὐδὲν δεινὸν ὧδ’ εἰπεῖν ἔπος οὐδὲ πάθος οὐδὲ ξυμφορὰ θεήλατος
msItem.explicit: f. 72v σὺν τυνδαρίδαις τοῖς διὸς υἱοῖς ναύταις μεδέουσα θαλάσσης· ὦ μέγα σεμνὴ νίκη· τὸν ἐμὸν βίοτον κατέχοις καὶ μὴ λήγοις στεφανοῦσα
msItem.note: The text is accompanied by scholia and interlinear glosses in brown ink

msItem.title: Hypothesis on Phoenician Women (Arg. 1 Dindorf, Scholia III 1863 = Arg. 1 Mastronarde-Bremer 1982 = a ed. Diggle 1994)
msItem.incipit: f. 73r Ἐτεοκλῆς παραλαβὼν τὴν τῶν θηβῶν βασιλείαν, τὸν ἀδελφὸν πολυνείκην ἀποστερεῖ τοῦ μέρους
msItem.explicit: f. 73r οἰδίπουν δὲ, φυγάδα τῆς πόλεως ἀπέπεμψατο· ἐφ' ὧν μὲν, ὁ φυλάξας ἀνθρώπων νόμους· ἐφ' ὧν δὲ τὴν ὀργὴν λογοποιήσας· οὐδὲ παρὰ τὴν δυστυχίαν ἐλεήσας
msItem.note: Followed by the list of characters of the play

msItem.author: Euripides
msItem.title: Phoenician Women
msItem.incipit: f. 73v Ὦ τὴν ἐν ἄστροις οὐρανοῦ τέμνων ὁδὸν καὶ χρυσοκολλήτοισιν ἐμβεβὼς δίφροις
msItem.explicit: f. 118r ὦ μέγα σεμνὴ νίκη· τὸν ἐμὸν βίοτον κατέχοις καὶ μὴ λήγοις στεφανοῦσα

support.material:
Western paper, folded in octavo. Quires 1-5, ff. 1r-41v (Hand A): Watermarks:
stair ( 70 20 ) on the gutter comparable to Briquet, 5911 , dated 1476-1494. Quires 5-12, 42r-118r (Hand B): eagle ( 50 50 ) on the gutter, comparable to Briquet, 91 but slightly smaller, dated 1494-1507 (?).

supportDesc.foliation: i-ii + 1-121 + iii. Modern foliation in pencil in Arabic numerals in the top right-hand corner, recto.

collation.p:
The manuscript consists of 12 quinions:
2 paper flyleaves (18th century)
Quires 1-1210 ff. 1r-121v
1 paper flyleaf (18th century)
collation.catchwords: Vertical catchwords placed along the inner bounding line, reading from top to bottom; by a later hand on f. 10v, by Hand B on ff. 40v, 50v, 60v, 70v, 80v, 90v, 100v.

signatures.p: A sequence of quire signatures in pencil in Arabic numerals is added in the bottom right-and corner of the first folio, recto of quires 2-12.
Bifolium signatures in pencil in Arabic numerals remain in the bottom right-hand corner of the first folio, recto of quires 5-12, partially lost in trimming.

condition.p: Generally in good condition. There are occasional stains, worm holes, and a blue ink stain on f. 75v

layoutDesc.layout:
ff. 42r-118r Hand B: written space 138 75
Main text varies between 19 (Hand B) and 22 (Hand A) lines per page, both in single columns. The scholia that accompany the main text have a very variable number of lines per page and the arrangement arranged in a orderly manner. The text of the scholia is sometimes shaped cul-de-lampe or following sinuous lines (e.g. ff. 28r, 38r).

handNote.p: Hand A: ff. 1r-41v, Hecuba, Orestes ll. 1-490.
A mixed minuscule script, with variable slant, in brown ink, with modest variation in letter size. Letters are hanging from the ruling line.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings usually appear only at the end of lines, but occasionally elsewhere (e.g. common abbreviation of μεν). Breathings are curved and joined to accents; mute iota is absent. Accents are often joined to alpha, upsilon and omega.

Alpha is drawn in two shapes: a rounded one and another one with a long oblique stroke; beta displays in bilobate shape; pi is in 'omega-like' shape, under a long horizontal stroke; tau is often high with an eyelet, especially when ligated to kappa; one of the two strokes of chi is prolonged in the lower left corner; psi is traced in the shape of a cross. The modern nu, small gamma, kappa, lambda and sigma telikon are present; the latter is angular and traced in four strokes.
The epsilon-rho ligature appears in a distinctive form in which the upper part forms a closed loop.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper point, lower comma and full stop.
Hand B: ff. 30r-30v, 42r-118r, Hypothesis on Orestes, Orestes ll. 491-end, Phoenissae, and scholia.

A mixed minuscule script, with very variable slant, in brown ink, with modest variation in letter size. Letters are mostly hanging from the ruling line. Hand B shows a more fluid and cursive tendency than Hand A.
Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings are rare and usually appear only at the end of lines. Breathings are curved and joined to accents; mute iota is absent.

Gamma is high; theta is open, often with a little downward fluttering; enlarged lunate sigma is used often at the beginning of words; tau is high and with an eyelet; lambda is positioned low and often with long descenders; the modern nu and sigma telikon are present.
Tails are occasionally flourished into the lower and outer margins.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper point, lower comma and full stop.

handDesc.handNote: Some Greek words occur in the text with Latin translation by a later hand (e.g. ff. 37r, 52r).

decoDesc.decoNote: Major initials in thick red ink and with floral patterns mark the start of the plays on ff. 1r, 31r and 73v. The initial of the Hypothesis on Phoenician Women, f. 73r, is outlined in red ink and decorated.
Simple initials in the arguments, and names in the lists of characters are outlined in red ink. The names of characters in plays are in red ink.

An ormamental vine leaf marks the end of Hecuba on f. 30r. The manuscript contains a sketch of a face, drawn in pale brown in the margins of f. 43v. Several maniculae marked the main text (e.g. ff. 6v-8r).

physDesc.additions: A 16th-century hand wrote on f. 1r: Liber quondam Theodori Archie(pisco)pi Cantuariensis

binding.p: 18th-century couched-laminate board binding covered in quarter with skin and parchment.

history.origin: The watermark of the paper used indicates that the manuscript was produced in the late 15th or early 16th century, a dating consistent with the style of script.

provenance.p:
The manuscript seems to come from Christ Church Cathedral Priory, Canterbury, and it was counted among the books believed to have belonged to Theodore of Tarsus (d. 690), archbishop of Canterbury Theodore, of Tarsus, Saint, Archbishop of Canterbury, 602-690 , as a 16th-century hand stated on f. 1r: Liber quondam Theodori Archie(pisco)pi Cantuariensis . This note was propably added by
William Sellyng Guilelmus Tillaeus ca. ca. 14301494 , known as Tilley or Tillaeus (d. 1494). Sellyng is among the first English men known to have studied Greek in Italy, and the monastery of Christ Church in Canterbury, of which he was prior from 1472 to 1494, was one of the earliest English centres in which Greek texts were studied; the manuscripts he collected passed into the Parker's collection.

history.acquisition:
The manuscript was bequeathed to Corpus Christi College by
Matthew Parker Parker, Matthew, 1504-1575 (b. 1504, d. 1575), Master of the College between 1544 and 1553, and Archbishop of Canterbury from 1559 until his death in 1575. It is listed in William Stanley's catalogue of 1722 at the classmark Q.7, which remains on f. 1r.

recordHist.source: Description (2019) draws on M.R. James, A descriptive catalogue of the manuscripts in the library of Corpus Christi College, Cambridge (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1912), vol. 2, p. 268-269.

availability.p: Visitors to Corpus Christi College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Parker Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Parker Library: Information for Readers.
